docs.lead_paragraph: Opening up yet another front in the legal assault on the tobacco industry, San Francisco sued yesterday to recover millions of dollars it spent on health problems attributed to smoking. Nine states have sued the tobacco industry seeking billions of dollars in compensation of state Medicaid spending to treat tobacco-related illnesses. But San Francisco's suit, the first by a local government, seeks reimbursement for spending on its poorest citizens that is not covered by the state or Federal Government and for the costs of providing insurance coverage for its own employees to cover such illnesses.

headline.main: San Francisco Joins Assault On Tobacco

docs.lead_paragraph: For the second time in 15 months, the Senate failed today to approve a proposed constitutional amendment that would require the Government to maintain a balanced budget. No one expected otherwise. The 64-to-35 vote, 2 short of the 66 votes needed for passage, ratified what everyone already knew: that the amendment's backers had lost ground when a supporter, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, resigned last year and was replaced by an opponent of the measure.

headline.main: Congress Is Moving On Political Issues, Not on Legislation

docs.lead_paragraph: Affiliated Computer Services Inc., which provides information technology services, signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Genix Group, a unit of the MCN Corporation, for $135 million in cash. The merger would create the nation's fourth-largest outside provider of data-processing services, with annual revenues of more than $500 million, Affiliated said. Genix mainly serves the manufacturing, insurance and utility industries, complementing Dallas-based Affiliated's strengths in the health care, financial services, transportation and telecommunications segments. Genix, based in Dearborn, Mich., had revenues of $105.2 million in 1995.

docs.lead_paragraph: An official Government report today confirmed that the Medicare system was running out of money faster than ever, setting off a new round of political backbiting. Republicans used the annual report of the trustees of the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund to attack President Clinton anew for vetoing budget legislation last year that would have put the program on a sounder financial footing.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the first day of a machinists' strike against McDonnell Douglas Corporation here, the company reassigned 1,500 engineers and white collar workers to assemble aircraft. As strikers picketed outside the heavily guarded plant, a company spokesman, Tom Williams, said McDonnell Douglas expected production to reach normal levels rapidly by using design engineers and others to assemble aircraft.

headline.main: McDonnell Douglas Is Working Despite Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Health Care Bill Draws Opposition on Key Provisions" (front page, May 26): State insurance officials are right to oppose the insurance pool provision in the House bill, which would help small businesses band together to get employee health insurance at reduced rates, because they know that by avoiding state regulation it would invite fraud, scam, abuse and insolvencies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dole returned to the Capitol today for his final week in the Senate and, as expected, promptly lost the first of several votes that he has scheduled in his attempt to draw a bright political line between himself and President Clinton. Today's vote, on almost straight party lines, was on a Republican effort to take up a bill that would require the United States to build a complete anti-missile defense system by 2003. The result was no surprise, and Mr. Dole also expects to lose another symbolic vote, which he has scheduled for Thursday, on a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget.

headline.main: Dole Begins a Final Week Of Senate Vote-Taking

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: How disappointing it is to see you parroting the party line of the insurance industry in recommending continued discrimination against the mentally ill ("Mr. Dole's Health-Care Task," editorial, May 30). There is only one remedy that serves both justice and human need: access to treatment for mental disorders fully equal to that for other diseases.

docs.lead_paragraph: At least a dozen of New York City's private hospitals are planning large-scale layoffs next month or are late in paying significant bills, concrete signals that the long-predicted financial crisis for the region's private hospitals has finally arrived. Squeezed by sharp Medicaid cuts and the rise of health maintenance organizations, a handful of private hospitals this month notified the city's principal hospital workers union that they intend to lay off 517 union members July 1, a huge increase from the usual rate of 50 a month. And many other hospital workers will lose their jobs as well. St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan will eliminate hundreds of positions from its work force on July 1, including 160 from the hospital workers union, 34 registered nurses and more than 100 supervisory jobs.

headline.main: PRIVATE HOSPITALS IN NEW YORK SIGNAL A DEEPENING CRISIS

docs.lead_paragraph: As it begins the last month of an unusually fractious session, the New York Legislature has not only failed to adopt a budget on time for a 12th straight year. Lawmakers have also been unable to agree on many other major proposals, suggesting that this could turn out to be one of their least productive gatherings in recent memory. When they began the annual six-month session in January, the leaders of the State Senate and the Assembly said they were working on an array of sweeping initiatives that they maintained were crucial for the state: deregulating hospitals, toughening sentences for some crimes, cutting the cost of workers' compensation, setting rules for health maintenance organizations and overhauling the way New York City's school system is governed.
